case_name: Debendra Nath Dutta v. Income-tax Investigation Commission and Union of India

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave by Debendra Nath Dutta against the report of the Income-tax Investigation Commission in R.C. No. 332A and orders passed by Central Government dated November 19, 1949 and November 21, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Kapur, J. This is an appeal by special leave against the report of the Income-tax Investigation Commission Made in R.C. No. 332A and the orders passed thereon by the Central Government dated November 19, 1949, and November 21, 1949, the former under section 8 2  and the latter under section 8A 1  of the Taxation on Income  Investigation Commission  Act  Act XXX of 1947   hereinafter to be referred as the Act .

facts.text: Appellant is Debendra Nath Dutta and respondents are Income-tax Investigation Commission and Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: the former under section 8 2  and the latter under section 8A 1  of the Taxation on Income  Investigation Commission  Act  Act XXX of 1947   hereinafter to be referred as the Act . The appellant is Debendra Nath Dutta and the respondents are the Income-tax Investigation Commission companystituted under section 3 of the Act  hereinafter referred to as the Commission  and the Union of India.

facts.text: Captain N. N. Dutta, brother of the appellant, was managing director of Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to the appeal are that Captain N. N. Dutta, a brother of the appellant was the managing director of a companycern called the Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd.

facts.text: During the last war, Captain N. N. Dutta made large profits which were concealed and escaped income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: During the last war he made large profits which were neither disclosed to number detected by the Income-tax Department and thus escaped income-tax on what may be termed companycealed income.

facts.text: On March 23, 1949, Commission made report to Central Government under section 5(4) asking for reference of Captain N. N. Dutta's case.

anchor.surface_text: On March 23, 1949, the Commission made a report to the Central Government under section 5 4  of the Act asking for reference to it self of the case of Captain N. N. Dutta.

facts.text: Commission directed search of four premises belonging to or occupied by Captain N. N. Dutta and his relations.

anchor.surface_text: Almost simultaneously the Commission directed a search to be made of four premises belonging to or in the occupation of Captain N. N. Dutta and his relations as a result of which companylete sets of books

facts.text: Search resulted in possession of complete sets of books containing receipts and disbursements of secret profits by Captain N. N. Dutta.

anchor.surface_text: as a result of which companylete sets of books companytaining receipts and disbursements of secret profits made by Captain N. N. Dutta came into the possession of the Commission and thus the case of Captain N. N. Dutta came to be investigated after reference to the Commission by the Central Government.

facts.text: Case of Captain N. N. Dutta is R.C. No. 332A.

anchor.surface_text: came into the possession of the Commission and thus the case of Captain N. N. Dutta came to be investigated after reference to the Commission by the Central Government. This case was R.C. No. 332A.

facts.text: Captain N. N. Dutta died on April 6, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: but a few days after this offer i.e., on April 6, 1949, he died leaving brothers, nephews and nieces who are shown in the following pedigree table Krishna Kumar Dutta XiXCD Kamini Kumar

facts.text: Captain N. N. Dutta was unmarried; elder brother Kamini Kumar Dutta, younger brother appellant Debendra Nath Dutta; another elder brother died leaving widow Charunalini Dutta.

anchor.surface_text: Kamini Kumar Dutta was his elder brother and the appellant Debendra Nath Dutta the younger brother. The deceased himself was unmarried. Another elder brother of his had died sometime before leaving a widow Charunalini Dutta.

facts.text: Substantial portion of concealed profits invested by Captain N. N. Dutta in names of nephews (sons of Kamini Kumar Dutta and their wives), niece Maya, widowed sister-in-law Charunalini Dutta, in Government securities and bank deposits.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the investigation it was found that a substantial portion of the companycealed profits was invested by the late Captain N. N. Dutta in the names of his nephews, the sons of Kamini Kumar Dutta and their respective wives, his niece Maya and his widowed sister-in-law Charunalini Dutta. These profits were invested in Government securities and bank Deposits.

facts.text: Kamini Kumar Dutta and Debendra Nath Dutta brought on record as legal representatives of deceased.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Captain N. N. Dutta his two brothers Kamini Kumar Dutta and the appellant Debendra Nath Dutta were brought on record as legal representatives.

facts.text: Kamini Kumar Dutta wrote to Commission that he had no connection with business but accepted obligation to pay as legal representative and advised sons to disclose.

anchor.surface_text: Kamini Kumar Dutta wrote to the Commission that he had numberconnection with the business of his late brother but as his legal representative he accepted his obligation to pay in full anything due to the State and he also advised his sons to disclose the true state of affairs and to pay whatever sum was justly due.

facts.text: Total concealed income earned and received by Captain N. N. Dutta during 1940-41 to 1947-48 is Rs. 58,24,023, accepted by Kamini Kumar Dutta and appellant.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of their companyoperation and from the books and materials which had been obtained on search of the premises the total amount of companycealed income earned land received by Captain N. N. Dutta during the accounting years 1940-41 to 1947-48, was found to be Rs. 58,24,023 and this was accepted to be companycealed income both by Kamini Kumar Dutta and the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant accepted the concealed income amount of Rs. 58,24,023 but submitted he had no assets of deceased.

anchor.surface_text: He accepted the amount but he submitted that he had numberassets of the deceased in his hands.

facts.text: Kamini Kumar Dutta's branch applied for composition under section 8A on July 5, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On July 5, 1949, Kamini Kumar Duttas branch made an application for companyposition under section 8A of the Act.

facts.text: Commission recommended settlement for Kamini Kumar Dutta branch for Rs. 29,74,480; appellant not party to it.

anchor.surface_text: This was recommended by the Commission who in their report stated that the settlement was for the purpose of recovery and was only with regard to Kamini Kumar Dutta and his sons and daughters-in-law but was number made with the appellant. ... The amount to be recovered from that branch came to Rs. 29,74,480.

facts.text: Central Government passed order on November 19, 1949 under section 8(2) directing proceedings against Kamini Kumar Dutta and appellant for Rs. 58,24,023.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Central Government passed two orders, one under section 8A of the Act on November 19, 1949, directing that appropriate proceedings under the Indian Income-tax Act and Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, be taken against Kamini Kumar Dutta and the appellant, heirs of the deceased, with a view to assess or reassess the aggregate income of Rs. 58,24,023

facts.text: Central Government order on November 21, 1949 accepted settlement of Kamini Kumar Dutta branch.

anchor.surface_text: The other order was passed on November 21, 1949, accepting the terms and companyditions of settlement offered by the branch of Kamini Kumar Dutta it directed that demand numberices be served by the Income-tax Officer under section 29 of the Income-tax Act

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, District III-A, Calcutta passed 8 income-tax, 6 excess profits tax, 2 business profits tax assessment orders on March 24, 1950, each for 1/8 of total concealed sum, against both brothers.

anchor.surface_text: On March 24, 1950, the Income-tax Officer, District III-A, Calcutta, passed 8 income-tax assessment orders, 6 excess profits tax assessment orders and two business profits tax assessment orders each in regard to 1/8 of the total sum companycealed. The assessees in all these orders were both the brothers of the deceased

facts.text: Branch of Kamini Kumar Dutta paying in accordance with composition terms, liability substantially discharged.

anchor.surface_text: We have been informed that the branch of Kamini Kumar Dutta have been paying in accordance with the terms of the companyposition and their liability has been very substantially discharged.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal on April 15, 1950 under section 85 for reference to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On April 15, 1950, the appellant applied to the Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, under section 8 5  of the Act for a reference to the High Court of Calcutta of 15 questions of law which ultimately were reduced to three.

facts.text: Commissioner rejected applications on October 3, 1951 as no question of law arose.

anchor.surface_text: but by an order dated October 3, 1951, he rejected the applications as in his opinion numberquestion of law arose out of the various assessment orders.

facts.text: High Court of Calcutta discharged rules on March 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court of Calcutta under section 8 5  of the Act read with section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act and rules were issued by the High Court but on March 3, 1952, they were discharged.

facts.text: Supreme Court refused special leave on September 28, 1953 against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the appellant applied to this companyrt for special leave but on September 28, 1953, leave was refused.

facts.text: Special leave granted against Commission's report dated November 16, 1949 and orders thereon.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then obtained special leave against the report of the Commission dated November 16, 1949, and the orders made thereon and that is how this appeal has companye before us.

facts.text: Total tax to be realised Rs. 52,34,663 divided into 8 equal parts in assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: The several assessment orders, income-tax assessment orders, excess profits tax assessment and business profits assessment orders, show that the total amount to be released as tax was Rs. 52,34,663 divided into 8 equal parts.
This is an appeal by special leave against the report of the Income-tax Investigation Commission Made in R.C. No. 332A and the orders passed thereon by the Central Government dated November 19, 1949,
the former under section 8 2  and the latter under section 8A 1  of the Taxation on Income  Investigation Commission  Act  Act XXX of 1947   hereinafter to be referred as the Act .

concepts.interpretation: Central Government had the power to direct proceedings to be taken under the Income-tax Act against the person to whose case the report related, which was the deceased, therefore against his heirs.

issues.text: Whether the appeal is competent in view of the High Court's refusal to direct a case to be stated on the questions of law raised or in view of the refusal by this Court to grant special leave against the order of the High Court

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to decide whether in view of the High Courts refusal to direct a case to be stated on the questions of law raised or in view of the refusal by this court to grant special leave against the order of the High Court the appeal is competent because in our opinion there is nosubstance in the appeal.

issues.text: Whether the liability of the legal representatives for tax on concealed income is joint such that composition/settlement under section 8A(1) by one legal representative discharges the liability of all others

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that the effect of section 24B 1  of the Income-tax Act is that the liability of the executors, administrators or other legal representatives in regard to the tax payable is the same as was the liability of the deceased person and that the tax is one and therefore the liability of the heirs of the deceased was one and joint. Consequently any composition made with any one of the legal representatives, in this case with Kamini Kumar Dutta and his branch of the family, operated as a discharge of liability of all the heirs and there was nofurther liability left which could be foisted on to the appellant or attach to any assets which might come into his possession thereafter.

issues.text: Whether under section 8(2) of the Act the Central Government can direct proceedings under the Income-tax Act against the heirs of the deceased to whose case the report relates
Whether settlement under section 8A(1) closes the investigation only insofar as it relates to the person who applied for it

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that the effect of section 24B 1  of the Income-tax Act is that the liability of the executors, administrators or other legal representatives in regard to the tax payable is the same as was the liability of the deceased person and that the tax is one and therefore the liability of the heirs of the deceased was one and joint. arguments.court_reasoning: No contractual liability involved; tax liability determined by provisions of Investigation Act

arguments.claim: Shaikh Sahad v. Krishna Mohan Basak supports that heirs cannot be held jointly liable like contractors under section 43 Contract Act

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on certain decided cases to support that argument. The first case is Shaikh Sahad v. Krishna Mohan Basak. In that case a co-sharer landlord brought a suit for arrears of rent against the heirs of the original tenant of whom two appeared and the third did not. A money decree was passed against the absent heir for the entire claim but it was held by the High Court that the suit being against the heirs they must be taken to have been recognized as one body of registered tenants holding a single holding and it was not a case of joint contract which could be enforced against any of the joint contractors and section 43 of the Contract Act was inapplicable where parties become jointly interested by operation of law in a contract by a single person.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d in accordance with the provisions of the Act. Under section 8 2  of the Act, on the report of the Investigation Commission the Central Government ha

arguments.court_reasoning: Cases inapplicable as no question of enforcing contractual liability arises here

arguments.claim: Kasi Kinkar Sen v. Satyendra Nath Bhadra supports joint or several liability depends on intention; one heir not liable for entire rent

anchor.surface_text: The next case relied upon, i.e., Kasi Kinkar Sen v. Satyendra Nath Bhadra and others, was a case under section 43 of the Contract Act where it was held that whether a promise is joint or several is a question of construction depending upon the intention of the parties to the contract and where several persons jointly inherit a tenancy one of the heirs cannot be made separately liable for the entire rent.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cases have no application to the facts; no contractual liability

arguments.claim: Cited cases inapplicable as no contractual liability being enforced; tax liability governed by Act

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion these cases have no application to the facts of the present case, because no question of enforcing any contractual liability, either against any of the contracting parties or their heirs, arises here. The tax payable in respect of the concealed income is indeed one, but the liability of the appellant and the other must be determined in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: Under section 8(2) Central Government has power to direct proceedings under Income-tax Act against heirs of person to whose case report relates
Section 8A(1) settlement applies only to person who applies; closes investigation only insofar as relates to that person
Composition by Kamini branch does not discharge appellant's liability; appellant liable for balance tax on assets he holds or receives

holdings.text: The cases cited by the appellant have no application to the present case because no question of enforcing contractual liability arises; the liability of the legal representatives must be determined in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion these cases have noapplication to the facts of the present case, because noquestion of enforcing any contractual liability, either against any of the contracting parties or their heirs, arises here. The tax payable in respect of the concealed income is indeed one, but the liability of the appellant and the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents on joint contractual liability inapplicable as tax liability is statutory, not contractual, and governed specifically by the Investigation Act.

holdings.text: Under section 8(2) of the Act, the Central Government has power to direct proceedings under the Income-tax Act against the heirs of the deceased person to whose case the Commission's report relates.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language empowers direction against the person concerned, who was deceased, hence valid against heirs.

holdings.text: A settlement under section 8A(1) of the Act closes the investigation only insofar as it relates to the person who applied for the composition.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual reading of section 8A(1) limits effect to the applicant.

holdings.text: The composition under section 8A(1) by Kamini Kumar Dutta's branch discharged only their liability; the appellant remains liable for the balance of the tax to the extent of any assets of the deceased in his possession or coming into his possession.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Settlement limited to applicants per s8A(1); tax liability satisfied pro tanto by recoveries from legal representatives as per Act's scheme.

holdings.text: The appeal is without merit and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our view this appeal is without any merit and is therefore dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's contentions rejected on statutory interpretation; no substance in appeal.
